image.altText: Gail Ferrari-Hirst and Russell Hirst embrace while standing

props.synopsis: Just 18 days before Russell Wayne Hirst died of a cardiac event in November 2021, superannuation giant Cbus cancelled his insurance policy, leaving the beneficiary of his account in a year-long fight to have her claim approved.

title.children: 'Absolutely unacceptable': Cbus cancels customer's insurance days before his death

image.altText: A dark and pointed ballistic missile pointing skyward on a backdrop of forestry

props.synopsis: The country's defence ministry says Ukraine fired six US-made tactical missiles known as ATACMS at a Russian military facility in the Bryansk border region.

title.children: Russia claims Ukraine fired six US-made missiles at a Russian military facility

image.altText: A man looks into camera with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Former military lawyer David McBride has given an interview to the ABC from the Canberra prison where he is serving a sentence of more than five years for leaking secret military documents to journalists.

title.children: 'It's a dangerous place': Whistleblower David McBride tells of his life in Canberra prison

image.altText: Donald Trump in front of a wall of American flags.

props.synopsis: It's now eight years since Salena Zito made probably the most pellucid observation of all about Trump: "The press takes him literally, but not seriously; his supporters take him seriously, but not literally."

title.children: The spectacle of WWE goes some way to explaining Trump's new cabinet appointments

image.altText: Photo of a young woman with red hair and nose piercings

props.synopsis: Detectives from the Missing Persons Squad have charged a 53-year-old man with murder and a 57-year-old man with assisted murder after the disappearance of 19-year-old Brunswick woman Isla Bell.

title.children: Man charged with murder after human remains found in search for missing Melbourne teenager Isla Bell

image.altText: A hooded man holds a laptop computer as cyber code is projected on him in this illustration picture

props.synopsis: Wealthy private schools are among the top targets of online hackers, according to a new report by Australia's cyber spy agency. Follow live.

title.children: Cyber spy agency warns private schools an attractive target for ransomware crooks

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Dutton 'spreading misinformation' over nuclear energy: Marles
Leaders, they're just like us: a dispatch from our man in Rio

image.altText: Central Station in Sydney

props.synopsis: Industrial action will freeze all train services across Greater Sydney from Friday to Sunday morning. Here is what the strike means for commuters.

title.children: Sydney's looming train shutdown set to cause 'massive disruption'

image.altText: Kusini Yengi  scores

props.synopsis: The Socceroos rescued a point late against Bahrain at the National Stadium in Riffa, having been stunned with two quick goals in the second half.

title.children: Socceroos strike late to level against Bahrain after being shocked by two goals in two minutes in World Cup qualifier

image.altText: Palestinians with backpack cary household items as they flee along an unsealed road that runs between damaged buildings.

props.synopsis: The IDF's siege of northern Gaza is now into its second month, leading many to question whether Israel has adopted a controversial plan to conquer the area.

title.children: Former general who plans to starve 'combatants' out of northern Gaza slams critics

image.altText: Boulevard of trees in central Melbourne

props.synopsis: Research shows Melbourne and Sydney are failing to meet the "bare minimum" standard for nature in cities based on "3-30-300" guidelines that assess tree visibility, canopy cover and access to parks.

title.children: Major Australian cities fail to pass 'bare minimum' nature standards

image.altText: Vladimir Putin wearing a dark suit, tie and blue shirt sitting emotionless at a wooden desk in front of a Russian flag

props.synopsis: The new doctrine says the Kremlin would consider a nuclear strike in response to the use of conventional weapons against Russia or Belarus.

title.children: Vladimir Putin lowers Russia's threshold for using nuclear weapons

image.altText: A woman with short auburn hair looks at the ground while walking through a door

props.synopsis: The Frenchwoman and her ex-husband have given their final statements in court as the mass rape trial involving 51 men enters its final stages.

title.children: Gisele Pelicot says mass rape trial of 51 men is one of 'cowardice'

image.altText: A woman with red hair sits in an office with brightly coloured wallpaper behind her

props.synopsis: The prolific wallpaper designer reinvented herself many times and embroidered her biography. But years after her death, her murderer is still unknown.

title.children: Florence Broadhurst's killer has never been found, and the cop who discovered her body wonders why

image.altText: A man's side profile.

props.synopsis: The government says a controversial ministerial directive will remain in place if it cannot pass its bill to cap international student enrolments from next year — a likely scenario due to the Coalition announcing it will vote against it.

title.children: Regional universities warn of 'disastrous' consequences if scheme to manage student visas remains in place

image.altText: Smokey rubble with house in background

props.synopsis: G20 summit calls for peace in the Ukraine-Russia and Middle East war, just before Russia claimed Ukraine had begun launching American-made long-range missiles into its territory.

title.children: World leaders call for peace in Ukraine-Russia war and Middle East

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

props.synopsis: Minutes from the RBA board's last meeting suggest a rate cut is not assured even if December inflation is low using the Reserve Bank's favoured "underlying" measure, which excludes volatile items.

title.children: RBA says February rate cut not guaranteed even if inflation figures rosy

image.altText: Chris Bowen doorstop

props.synopsis: The announcement was made at the United Nations climate summit in Azerbaijan. Climate economists say rich countries will need to commit much more money to make a difference.

title.children: Australia commits additional $50 million to deal with climate change

image.altText: Harry Armstrong and Harvey Langford pose together for a photo

props.synopsis: The AFL draft offers struggling clubs a ticket back to the top, but not every team approaches it in the same way. The stakes are high for Richmond, West Coast and others and their radically different draft strategies are about to be put to the test.

title.children: The futures of Richmond, West Coast and others may well be shaped by what happens tonight and tomorrow

image.altText: Woman wearing a white sundress with brown hair.

props.synopsis: More than 3,000 children who contact Kids Helpline every year report being bullied. A new school behaviour and management plan to be implemented by term one, 2025 will make it mandatory for NSW schools to identify, prevent and respond to disruptive student behaviours, including bullying and cyberbullying.

title.children: Parents move their kids to new schools as teachers fail to deal with bullies

image.altText: overflowing storm drains

props.synopsis: Rains that have saturated an already sodden south-east are expected to head north before easing off for the weekend.

title.children: Coldest November day in 16 years forecast for Brisbane as wet weather continues across Queensland

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Local shares could edge lower at the open after a mixed finish on Wall Street, as investors brushed off an escalation of the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Worsening housing affordability has seen demand for apartments jump, according to research from ANZ and CoreLogic. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX to edge lower, Wall Street mixed as investors assess Russia-Ukraine tensions

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Businesses failing at near highest rate on record
Business alliance against domestic and family violence
Amcor to buy US packaging giant Berry Global

image.altText: A "sorry we're closed" sign in the window of a shopfront.

props.synopsis: The rate of business failures is now the highest it has been since the COVID-19 pandemic, and it is only set to grow as the cost of doing business squeezes companies from all sides.

title.children: Businesses are failing at near the highest rate on record

image.altText: Screengrab of mobile vision showing people with blurred faces standing under an awning.

props.synopsis: South Australia's Attorney-General and Aboriginal Affairs Minister Kyam Maher has spoken to the state's Police Commissioner, following "confronting" footage taken during an arrest near Port Augusta at the weekend.

title.children: Circumstances of 'confronting' vision in 'public interest', police say

image.altText: A man breaks a white car's window with a long object.

props.synopsis: Police have arrested a man after a car drove into primary school students, injuring a number of people in Changade.

title.children: Man drives car into primary school children in China

image.altText: A long exposure shows a nuclear plant illuminated at night, with a white cloud of steam emerging from the top of two reactors.

props.synopsis: Acting Prime Minister Richard Marles says the agreement, which Australia had been expected to join, is not relevant to the country's circumstances.

title.children: Australia declines to join UK and US-led nuclear energy development pact

image.altText: Donald Trump hush money case

props.synopsis: Prosecutors who secured Donald Trump's conviction over a hush money payment say they will accept a delay in the case as the incoming president seeks to have it dismissed.

title.children: New York prosecutors accept delay on Trump hush money sentencing

image.altText: Three poker machines in a club with brightly coloured screens showing different gambling games, with three empty stools in front

props.synopsis: It seems despite the Tasmanian government's assurances it wouldn't back down from its commitment to pokies reform, long-held concerns the premier would walk back support for a cashless gaming card were on the money.

title.children: Tasmania's resolve for chasing nation-leading gambling reform accused of collapsing like a house of cards

image.altText: A woman stands for a mugshot holding a corrections board

props.synopsis: Susan Smith is facing a parole board for the first time more than three decades after she confessed to killing her two sons and lying about their abduction.

title.children: Susan Smith's ex fights to keep her in jail 30 years after she claimed their sons were abducted and murdered

image.altText: readbook2

props.synopsis: A government department says it will stop partnering with a charity run by Plymouth Brethren Christian Church members. A school run by church members has also been referred to regulators following allegations that students are discouraged from attending on-campus university.

title.children: SA Health to cut ties with charity run by Brethren members, school referred to regulators

image.altText: Side-by-side photos of Bianca Jones and Holly Bowles, two Melbourne teens who have been hospitalised in Thailand

props.synopsis: The parents of Holly Bowles and Bianca Jones remain at their bedsides in separate Thai hospitals as the Melbourne women fight for their lives after drinking tainted alcohol.

title.children: Teens were on 'incredible adventure' through Asia before apparent methanol poisoning in Laos

image.altText: Spencer Porter

props.synopsis: The Victorian consumer watchdog alleges Spencer Porter, 25, accepted $1.3 million to build tiny homes but failed to supply them in a reasonable time.

title.children: Young entrepreneur faces charges for accepting $1.3 million in payments and failing to supply tiny homes

image.altText: A Woolworths branded trolley connected to a Coles branded trolley.

props.synopsis: 'Colesworth', a portmanteau referring to the perceived duopoly of supermarket retailers Coles and Woolworths, is the Australian National Dictionary Centre's Word of the Year for 2024.

title.children: Word of the Year reflects increasing frustration with Australia's top supermarkets

image.altText: A woman on a beach with severely weathered ropes around her neck

props.synopsis: Kangaroo Island tour guides Mia Bertetto and Nikki Redman say they have a blunt message for tourists and locals — "Don't garbage paradise".

title.children: The 'heartbreaking, never-ending' rubbish on Kangaroo Island
